message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Observer-Based Dynamic Event-Triggered Control for Multiagent Systems With Time-Varying Delay
Paper Abstract: This article is concerned with the dynamic event-triggered-based adaptive output-feedback tracking control problem of nonlinear multiagent systems with time-varying input delay. By utilizing the approximation capability of neural network (NN), a low-gain nonlinear observer is first established to estimate the immeasurable states. To mitigate the effect of time-varying input delay, an auxiliary system with communication information is designed to generate the compensation signals. Then, a distributed adaptive composite NN dynamic surface control (DSC) strategy is proposed to acquire the satisfactory tracking accuracy, where the filter errors are compensated by the introduced serial-parallel estimation model. Moreover, an effective switching dynamic event-triggered mechanism is developed to determine the communication instants and reduce the update frequency of the controller. It is proven that the consensus tracking error converges to a residual set of the origin. Finally, simulation results are presented to demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed composite NN DSC scheme.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

Based on the search results, I found relevant information about event-triggered control. Here's what I found:

Event-triggered control is a research area focused on the analysis and design of event-triggered systems, as evidenced by recognition in the field. Maurice Heemels, a Full Professor at Eindhoven University of Technology, was named IEEE Fellow in 2016 for contributions to analysis and design of hybrid, networked, and event-triggered systems.

Event-triggered control is distinct from time-triggered control systems. While time-triggered systems execute tasks according to a predetermined and set task schedule, event-triggered control systems operate differently—they respond to specific events rather than fixed time intervals.

The search results indicate that event-triggered control is an important research area in control theory, particularly relevant for networked and hybrid systems, though the results don't provide extensive detail about the specific technical implementation or applications of event-triggered control systems.

Here are the search results for "multiagent systems":

## Overview

A multi-agent system (MAS) is a computerized system composed of multiple interacting intelligent agents.(no content)Multi-agent systems can solve problems that are difficult or impossible for an individual agent or a monolithic system to solve.

## Key Characteristics

Agents in a multi-agent system have important characteristics including autonomy (agents are at least partially independent, self-aware, autonomous), local views (no agent has a full global view), and decentralization (no agent is designated as controlling).(no content)With advancements in large language models (LLMs), LLM-based multi-agent systems have emerged as a new area of research, enabling more sophisticated interactions and coordination among agents.

## Applications and Related Fields

Applications where multi-agent systems research may deliver an appropriate approach include online trading, disaster response, target surveillance and social structure modelling.(no content)Multi-agent reinforcement learning (MARL) is a sub-field of reinforcement learning that focuses on studying the behavior of multiple learning agents that coexist in a shared environment.(no content)The International Conference on Autonomous Agents and Multiagent Systems (AAMAS) is the leading scientific conference for research in the areas of artificial intelligence, autonomous agents, and multiagent systems.

Web search results for query: "neural network"

Links: [{"title":"Neural network (machine learning) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Neural_network_(machine_learning)"},{"title":"Neural network - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Neural_network"},{"title":"Physical neural network - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Physical_neural_network"},{"title":"Neural network (biology) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Biological_neural_network"},{"title":"Convolutional neural network - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Convolutional_neural_network"},{"title":"Graph neural network - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Graph_neural_network"},{"title":"History of artificial neural networks - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_artificial_neural_networks"},{"title":"Energy-based generative neural network","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Energy-based_generative_neural_network"},{"title":"Feedback neural network - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Feedback_neural_network"},{"title":"File:Artificial Neural Network.gif","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Artificial_Neural_Network.gif"}]

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about neural networks:

## Definition and Structure

A neural network consists of connected units or nodes called artificial neurons, which loosely model the neurons in the brain.(no content)Neurons in an artificial neural network are usually arranged into layers, with information passing from the first layer (the input layer) through one or more intermediate layers (the hidden layers) to the final layer (the output layer).

## Applications

Neural networks are used to solve problems in artificial intelligence, and have thereby found applications in many disciplines, including predictive modeling, adaptive control, facial recognition, handwriting recognition, general game playing, and generative AI.

## How Neural Networks Learn

Neural networks are typically trained through empirical risk minimization, which is based on the idea of optimizing the network's parameters to minimize the difference, or empirical risk, between the predicted output and the actual target values in a given dataset.(no content)Gradient-based methods such as backpropagation are usually used to estimate the parameters of the network.

## Types of Neural Networks

Several specialized types exist, including:
- Convolutional neural networks (CNN), which are a type of feedforward neural network that learns features via filter optimization, and have been applied to process and make predictions from many different types of data including text, images and audio.
- Graph neural networks (GNN) are specialized artificial neural networks that are designed for tasks whose inputs are graphs.

## Historical Development

Today's deep neural networks are based on early work in statistics over 200 years ago.

Web search results for query: "adaptive control"

Links: [{"title":"Adaptive control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adaptive_control"},{"title":"Adaptive cruise control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adaptive_cruise_control"},{"title":"Adaptive collaborative control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adaptive_collaborative_control"},{"title":"Self-tuning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Self-tuning"},{"title":"Adaptive traffic control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adaptive_traffic_control"},{"title":"Continuous monitoring and adaptive control (stormwater management) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Continuous_monitoring_and_adaptive_control_(stormwater_management)"},{"title":"Xbox Adaptive Controller - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Xbox_Adaptive_Controller#:~:text=The co-creator of the,much they could be ..."},{"title":"Real-time adaptive security - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Real-time_adaptive_security"},{"title":"File:Xbox Adaptive Controller V&A.JPG - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Xbox_Adaptive_Controller_V&A.JPG"},{"title":"Adaptive autonomy","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adaptive_autonomy"}]

Here are the search results for "adaptive control":

## Main Concept

Adaptive control is the control method used by a controller which must adapt to a controlled system with parameters which vary, or are initially uncertain.(no content)For example, as an aircraft flies, its mass will slowly decrease as a result of fuel consumption; a control law is needed that adapts itself to such changing conditions.

## Key Distinction

Adaptive control is different from robust control in that it does not need a priori information about the bounds on these uncertain or time-varying parameters; robust control guarantees that if the changes are within given bounds the control law need not be changed, while adaptive control is concerned with control law changing itself.

## Technical Foundation

The foundation of adaptive control is parameter estimation, which is a branch of system identification. Common methods of estimation include recursive least squares and gradient descent.

## Types of Adaptive Control

The search results identify several approaches:

- Direct methods wherein the estimated parameters are those directly used in the adaptive controller, while indirect methods are those in which the estimated parameters are used to calculate required controller parameters.
- Model reference adaptive controllers (MRACs) incorporate a reference model defining desired closed loop performance.

## Applications

A particularly successful application of adaptive control has been adaptive flight control.

- Direct methods wherein the estimated parameters are those directly used in the adaptive controller, while indirect methods are those in which the estimated parameters are used to calculate required controller parameters.
- Model reference adaptive controllers (MRACs) incorporate a reference model defining desired closed loop performance.

## Applications

A particularly successful application of adaptive control has been adaptive flight control.

Here are the search results for "nonlinear system control":

## Overview

Nonlinear control theory is the area of control theory which deals with systems that are nonlinear, time-variant, or both.(no content)Nonlinear control theory covers a wider class of systems that do not obey the superposition principle and applies to more real-world systems, because all real control systems are nonlinear.

## Key Characteristics

These systems are often governed by nonlinear differential equations.(no content)The mathematical techniques which have been developed to handle them are more rigorous and much less general, often applying only to narrow categories of systems, including limit cycle theory, Poincaré maps, Lyapunov stability theory, and describing functions.

## Analysis and Design Approaches

If only solutions near a stable point are of interest, nonlinear systems can often be linearized by approximating them by a linear system obtained by expanding the nonlinear solution in a series, and then linear techniques can be used. Additionally, nonlinear systems are often analyzed using numerical methods on computers, for example by simulating their operation using a simulation language.

## Example Application

An example of a nonlinear control system is a thermostat-controlled heating system, where a building heating system such as a furnace has a nonlinear response to changes in temperature; it is either "on" or "off".

## Advanced Techniques

Nonlinear model predictive control, or NMPC, is a variant of model predictive control that is characterized by the use of nonlinear system models in the prediction.

Links: [{"title":"Consensus (computer science) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Consensus_(computer_science)"},{"title":"Distributed version control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Distributed_version_control_system"},{"title":"Consensus dynamics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Consensus_dynamics"},{"title":"Paxos (computer science) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Paxos_(computer_science)"},{"title":"Raft (algorithm) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Raft_(algorithm)"},{"title":"State machine replication - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/State_machine_replication"},{"title":"Atomic broadcast - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Atomic_broadcast"},{"title":"Byzantine fault - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Byzantine_fault"},{"title":"Distributed control system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Distributed_Control_System"},{"title":"Category:Distributed algorithms - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Distributed_algorithms"}]

Based on the search results, here's what I found about consensus tracking and distributed control:

## Consensus Dynamics and Tracking

Consensus dynamics, also known as agreement dynamics, is an area of research at the intersection of systems theory and graph theory. It studies how a group of agents—such as robots, sensors, or decision-makers—interacting over a network can reach a common decision or estimate through local rules and information exchange.(no content)This is known as the consensus problem in multi-agent systems, where the goal is to ensure that all agents eventually agree on a certain quantity, despite starting with potentially different initial values.(no content)Consensus dynamics has applications in areas such as physiological systems, gene regulatory networks, large-scale energy systems, and coordinated control of autonomous vehicle fleets on land, in the air, or in space.

## Distributed Control Systems

Distributed control systems (DCS) are dedicated systems used in manufacturing processes that are continuous or batch-oriented.(no content)The key attribute of a DCS is its reliability due to the distribution of the control processing around nodes in the system. This mitigates a single processor failure. If a processor fails, it will only affect one section of the plant process, as opposed to a failure of a central computer which would affect the whole process.

## Applications

Real-world applications often requiring consensus include cloud computing, clock synchronization, PageRank, opinion formation, smart power grids, state estimation, control of UAVs (and multiple robots/agents in general), load balancing, blockchain, and others.

Links: [{"title":"Delay differential equation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Delay_differential_equation"},{"title":"Control theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control_theory"},{"title":"Group delay and phase delay - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Group_delay_and_phase_delay"},{"title":"Digital delay generator - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Digital_delay_generator"},{"title":"Timer - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timer"},{"title":"Delay (audio effect) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tape_echo"},{"title":"Delay-locked loop - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Delay-locked_loop"},{"title":"Delay box - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Delay_box"},{"title":"Time control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Time_control"},{"title":"Delay - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Delay"}]

I've completed the web search for "time delay systems control." Here are the key findings:

## Overview

Delay differential equations (DDEs) are a type of differential equation in which the derivative of the unknown function at a certain time is given in terms of the values of the function at previous times. DDEs are also called time-delay systems, systems with aftereffect or dead-time, hereditary systems, equations with deviating argument, or differential-difference equations.

## Control Engineering Challenges

The interest for DDEs keeps on growing in all scientific areas and, especially, in control engineering. However, delay systems are still resistant to many classical controllers, and ignoring effects which are adequately represented by DDEs is not a general alternative: in the best situation (constant and known delays), it leads to the same degree of complexity in the control design.(no content)In worst cases (time-varying delays, for instance), it is potentially disastrous in terms of stability and oscillations.

## System Characteristics

DDEs belong to the class of systems with a functional state, i.e. partial differential equations (PDEs) which are infinite dimensional, as opposed to ordinary differential equations (ODEs) having a finite dimensional state vector.(no content)Similar to ODEs, many properties of linear DDEs can be characterized and analyzed using the characteristic equation.

The search results indicate that time delay systems represent a significant area of research in control engineering, with particular challenges in handling time-varying delays and maintaining system stability.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

## Feedback Control System

I found comprehensive information about feedback control systems. Here are the key details:

### Definition and Basic Concept

A feedback controller (or closed-loop controller) is a control loop which incorporates feedback, in contrast to an open-loop controller. A closed-loop controller uses feedback to control states or outputs of a dynamical system.

The name comes from the information path in the system: process inputs (e.g., voltage applied to an electric motor) have an effect on the process outputs (e.g., speed or torque of the motor), which is measured with sensors and processed by the controller; the result (the control signal) is "fed back" as input to the process, closing the loop.

### How It Works

The controller monitors the controlled process variable (PV), and compares it with the reference or set point (SP). The difference between actual and desired value of the process variable, called the error signal, is applied as feedback to generate a control action to bring the controlled process variable to the same value as the set point.

### Practical Example

An everyday example is the cruise control on a road vehicle; where external influences such as hills would cause speed changes, and the driver has the ability to alter the desired set speed. The PID algorithm in the controller restores the actual speed to the desired speed in an optimum way, with minimal delay or overshoot, by controlling the power output of the vehicle's engine.

### Advantages

Closed-loop controllers have the following advantages over open-loop controllers: disturbance rejection (such as hills in the cruise control example above) guaranteed performance even with model uncertainties.

message_text:
Web search results for query: "observer state estimation control"

Links: [{"title":"State observer - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/State_observer"},{"title":"Active disturbance rejection control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Active_disturbance_rejection_control"},{"title":"Separation principle - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Separation_principle"},{"title":"Linear–quadratic–Gaussian control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Linear–quadratic–Gaussian_control"},{"title":"Observability - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Observability"},{"title":"State-space representation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/State-space_representation"},{"title":"Observer pattern - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Observer_pattern?amp=&amp="},{"title":"Kalman filter - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kalman_filter"},{"title":"State estimation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/?redirect=no&title=State_estimation"},{"title":"Observer - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Observer_(physics)"}]

Here are the search results for "observer state estimation control":

## Overview

In control theory, a state observer, state estimator, or Luenberger observer is a system that provides an estimate of the internal state of a given real system, from measurements of the input and output of the real system.(no content)It is typically computer-implemented, and provides the basis of many practical applications.

## Purpose and Application

Knowing the system state is necessary to solve many control theory problems; for example, stabilizing a system using state feedback.(no content)In most practical cases, the physical state of the system cannot be determined by direct observation. Instead, indirect effects of the internal state are observed by way of the system outputs.

## Key Concept

If a system is observable, it is possible to fully reconstruct the system state from its output measurements using the state observer.

## Types of Observers

Linear, delayed, sliding mode, high gain, Tau, homogeneity-based, extended and cubic observers are among several observer structures used for state estimation of linear and nonlinear systems.

## Related Control Theory Concepts

In control theory, a separation principle states that under some assumptions the problem of designing an optimal feedback controller for a stochastic system can be solved by designing an optimal observer for the state of the system, which feeds into an optimal deterministic controller for the system. Thus the problem can be broken into two separate parts, which facilitates the design.

## Popular Implementation: Kalman Filter

The Kalman filter is an efficient recursive filter estimating the internal state of a linear dynamic system from a series of noisy measurements.

message_text:
1. [completed] Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. [completed] List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. [completed] For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. [completed] Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple: name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm"), relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes), entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other, wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/), relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. [in_progress] Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. [pending] If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

message_text:
Excellent! Analysis complete. Here's a summary of what I've done:

## Analysis Summary

**Paper Classification**: `contribution` - The paper proposes novel methods for control and signal processing in multiagent systems.

**Extracted Triples** (9 entities):

1. **Event-driven architecture** (proposes) - The paper introduces a novel switching dynamic event-triggered mechanism
2. **Multi-agent system** (uses) - The paper addresses control of systems with multiple agents
3. **Delay differential equation** (uses) - Time-varying delays are handled through compensation techniques
4. **Neural network (machine learning)** (uses) - Used for function approximation in observers and controllers
5. **Closed-loop controller** (uses) - Output-feedback control structure for state estimation
6. **Adaptive control** (uses) - Handles uncertain and time-varying system parameters
7. **Consensus dynamics** (uses) - Ensures agents reach agreement on tracking objectives
8. **Nonlinear control** (uses) - The paper addresses nonlinear multiagent systems
9. **State observer** (uses) - A low-gain nonlinear observer estimates immeasurable states

**Validation Status**: ✅ All checks passed successfully!

The analysis correctly identified at least one "proposes" relation (event-triggered control) and multiple "uses" relations, meeting all validation requirements.

Sources:
- [Event-driven architecture](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Event-driven_architecture)
- [Multi-agent system](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multi-agent_system)
- [Delay differential equation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Delay_differential_equation)
- [Neural network (machine learning)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Neural_network_(machine_learning))
- [Closed-loop controller](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Closed-loop_controller)

- [Nonlinear control](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nonlinear_control)
- [State observer](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/State_observer)
